title: P06-1018

sentences.text: This paper proposes a generic mathematical formalism for the combination of various structures : strings , trees , dags , graphs , and products of them .
The polarization of the objects of the elementary structures controls the saturation of the final structure .
This formalism is both elementary and powerful enough to strongly simulate many grammar formalisms , such as rewriting systems , dependency grammars , TAG , HPSG and LFG .

Entity-a_generic_mathematical_formalism.label: a generic mathematical formalism
Entity-a_generic_mathematical_formalism.description: A generic mathematical formalism that facilitates the combination of various data structures, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, while controlling the saturation of the resulting structure through the polarization of elementary objects.

Entity-elementary_structure.label: elementary structures
Entity-elementary_structure.description: Elementary structures refer to fundamental components or configurations, such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, that are combined in a mathematical formalism to influence the properties and saturation of more complex structures in the context of grammar formalisms.

Entity-structure.label: structures
Entity-structure.description: The term 'structures' refers to various mathematical objects such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, which can be combined using a proposed formalism to simulate different grammar formalisms.

Entity-object.label: objects
Entity-object.description: In this context, 'objects' refers to the fundamental components of various mathematical structures, such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, which are manipulated within a proposed formalism to influence the saturation of the resulting structure.

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a mathematical framework for integrating various data structures, including strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs, while demonstrating its capability to simulate multiple grammar formalisms.

Entity-polarization.label: polarization
aliases: the polarization of the objects of the elementary structures
Entity-polarization.description: In this context, 'polarization' refers to a mathematical property that influences how the objects of elementary structures interact and combine, specifically affecting the saturation of the resulting structure in a formalism that integrates various types of data structures.

mentions.local_name: the polarization of the objects of the elementary structures

Entity-tree.label: trees
Entity-tree.description: In this paper, 'trees' refer to a type of mathematical object and data structure used in the proposed formalism for combining various structures, including strings, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs.

Entity-product.label: products
Entity-product.description: In this paper, 'products' refers to the mathematical constructs resulting from the combination of various structures such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs within a proposed formalism.

Entity-saturation.label: saturation
aliases: the saturation of the final structure
Entity-saturation.description: In this context, 'saturation' refers to a mathematical property that describes the extent to which the final structure, formed by combining various elementary structures, is filled or completed based on the polarization of those structures.

mentions.local_name: the saturation of the final structure

Entity-final_structure.label: final structure
Entity-final_structure.description: The 'final structure' refers to the resulting composite structure formed by the combination and saturation of various elementary structures, influenced by their polarization, within a mathematical formalism proposed in the paper.

Entity-graph.label: graphs
Entity-graph.description: In this paper, 'graphs' refer to mathematical objects that are part of a generic formalism for combining various data structures, including strings, trees, and directed acyclic graphs (dags).

Entity-string.label: strings
Entity-string.description: In this paper, 'strings' refer to sequences of characters or symbols that are treated as fundamental data structures within a mathematical formalism for combining various structures such as trees, dags, and graphs.

Entity-tag.label: TAG
Entity-tag.description: TAG refers to Tree Adjoining Grammar, a formal grammar framework that allows for the combination of tree structures to generate complex syntactic representations.

Entity-product_of_them.label: products of them
Entity-product_of_them.description: The term 'products of them' refers to the mathematical combinations or structures that can be formed by integrating various elementary structures such as strings, trees, directed acyclic graphs (dags), and graphs within the proposed formalism.

Entity-rewriting_system.label: rewriting systems
Entity-rewriting_system.description: Rewriting systems are formal systems used in computational models and formal grammars that define how strings or structures can be transformed into other strings or structures through the application of specific rules.

Entity-grammar_formalism.label: grammar formalisms
Entity-grammar_formalism.description: Grammar formalisms are structured systems or frameworks used to define the syntax and semantics of languages, often employing formal mathematical techniques to describe grammatical rules and structures.

Entity-mathematical_formalism.label: mathematical formalism
Entity-mathematical_formalism.description: Mathematical formalism refers to a structured and systematic approach to representing mathematical concepts and relationships using symbols, rules, and frameworks that facilitate analysis and problem-solving.

Entity-hpsg.label: HPSG
Entity-hpsg.description: HPSG, or Head-Driven Phrase Structure Grammar, is a formal grammar framework used in computational linguistics and linguistic theory that emphasizes the role of heads in syntactic structures and integrates both syntactic and semantic information.

Entity-dependency_grammar.label: dependency grammars
Entity-dependency_grammar.description: Dependency grammars are a type of formal grammar that represent the syntactic structure of sentences through the relationships between words, focusing on the dependencies between them rather than hierarchical phrase structures.

Entity-lfg.label: LFG
Entity-lfg.description: LFG, or Lexical Functional Grammar, is a formal grammar framework used in linguistic theory that emphasizes the relationship between syntax and semantics.

Entity-dag.label: dags
Entity-dag.description: DAGs, or Directed Acyclic Graphs, are a type of data structure and mathematical object used to represent relationships with directed edges that do not form cycles, allowing for the modeling of hierarchical and sequential relationships in various computational and mathematical contexts.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, theories, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

summary: This paper proposes a generic mathematical formalism for the combination of various structures : strings , trees , dags , graphs , and products of them . The polarization of the objects of the elementary structures controls the saturation of the final structure . This formalism is both elementary and powerful enough to strongly simulate many grammar formalisms , such as rewriting systems , dependency grammars , TAG , HPSG and LFG .

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject puts forward an idea, suggestion, or plan for consideration, typically aiming to introduce a new concept, theory, or method represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is actively engaging in the act of proposing, while the object is the content or proposal being suggested.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' establishes a relationship where the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part of its broader category or composition. It indicates that the object is a component, element, or subset that is contained within the subject.

Predicate-is_part_of.label: is part of
Predicate-is_part_of.description: The predicate 'is part of' indicates a relationship where the subject is a component, element, or constituent of the object. It signifies that the subject contributes to the overall composition or functionality of the object, suggesting a hierarchical or integrative connection between the two entities.

Predicate-controls.label: controls
Predicate-controls.description: The predicate 'controls' indicates a relationship where the subject exerts influence or authority over the object, determining its state, behavior, or characteristics. It implies a directional influence, suggesting that changes in the subject will affect the object in some manner.

Predicate-simulates.label: simulates
Predicate-simulates.description: The predicate 'simulates' indicates that the subject possesses the capability to replicate or model the behavior, characteristics, or processes of the object within a certain framework or context. This relationship suggests that the subject can provide insights or predictions about the object by mimicking its operations or outcomes, thereby establishing a functional or theoretical correspondence between the two.

Predicate-facilitates_the_combination_of.label: facilitates the combination of
Predicate-facilitates_the_combination_of.description: The predicate 'facilitates the combination of' indicates that the subject provides support, tools, or mechanisms that enable the merging, integration, or synthesis of the object with other elements. It implies an active role of the subject in making the process of combination easier or more efficient, thereby enhancing the interaction or relationship between the subject and the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset of a more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider range of concepts or entities than the subject, thereby situating the subject within a broader context.
